The song is basically about the rap wars and how much the danger of being hurt or killed by your rivals is highly possible. Eminem sings a little about most of his feuds with multiple artists and the video is just what could possibly happen to someone from his crew due to all of the fighting between the groups. The person that dies in the video actually dies 2 years later after the song was made. He was shot in a bar after shooting someone over a game of pool.

There are some people that he has named, I will try to clarify the situation.

Benzino is an older rapper, whom had control over Source magazine for a while and used it to bash on Eminem and even made a new album with a lot of songs directed to Eminem and I'm assuming that Eminem believed Benzino was irrelevant to everything that was going on and decided to try to be on top of the rap game by starting drama with him.

50 Cent's feud is said to be started in his words that Ja Rule was robbed out of his jewelry and Ja Rule thought 50 Cent had something to do with it and Ja Rule said that 50 Cent was jealous over the fact that when he was making videos in his 'hood, he got a lot of love from the people there. That's when they started to make diss song at each other with Ja Rule and Murder Inc artists and 50 Cent with his G-Unit. 50 Cent was nearly killed after being shot 9 times. It's said that a local drug kingpin sent the hit after 50 Cent made an album that exposed Murder Inc's illegal activties with the said drug dealer. It's also believed that the same drug dealer killed Jam Master Jay for helping out 50 Cent make and send the album and pretty much taught 50 Cent how to actually make music. 50 Cent later joined in Eminem's record label and Ja Rule threatened Eminem and Dre to not make any diss songs about him and they didn't until Dre produced a 50 Cent song that pretty much destroyed Ja Rule and his family and that's when Ja Rule came out with ''Loose Change'' and it was directed to Dre and Eminem and people from their labels and that's when Eminem/D12, Dr. Dre, 50 Cent/G-Unit battled Ja Rule/Murder Inc and other artists for a while. There was a time where Dre and Eminem talked with 50 Cent to try kill the drama with Ja Rule, but Ja Rule was talking and joking about how he was the one that stabbed 50 Cent in a club and that continued the fued. It was actually Black Child from Murder Inc that stabbed 50 Cent because he thought he was pulling out a gun.

Now to the Suge Knight thing. Eminem wasn't afraid of Suge Knight, he just didn't attack Suge Knight out of respect for his friend Dr. Dre who told him to stay out of it because it wasn't his beef and wanted to do things by himself.

I have been a fan of Eminem's music since I was in grade school. He is an awesome lyricist and truly has talent. The reason he is so popular is not solely because of his persona or lyrics, it is because he made something out of nothing. Growing up in Detroit may not have been the easiest lifestyle for Eminem when he was a child. This is what inspired him to become what he is today. He doesn't make music to please people, he makes music to vent his emotions, speak his opinion, and/or just have fun with his musical talent. I stumbled across this site because I was curious as to what word was edited from the explicit version of Like Toy Soldiers, but I didn't expect to find so much controversy. Take Eminem for what he is worth to YOU, for everyone is entitled to their own opinion.

I'm sure Eminem's music serves as a motivating/comforting factor for many underprivileged youths who know exactly what it was like to grow up in similar households. For others, it may just be entertainment, however, to those that it truly means something to, don't let so-called "educated people" dictate what is good or bad music. Often times these critics have never felt what it was like to come from nothing and become something.

...and that's all I have to say about that.Edited by random_monkey on January 29 2006, at 09:24AM

comment_121:
I am a big Eminem fan since before he was famous, I used to go to his underground shows, back in the ICP and Kid Rock days.

Em's feud with ICP is more a comical thing, ICP poses no threat to Eminem and vise versa. They simply had a fallout and cannot work together, so they chose to work against eachother. Suge is the (?). But you want to know something, it's actually quite obvious? Eminem doesn't want to be another victim himself especially, and Suge is not somebody to mess with, Suge is a murderer and a bully. That's why Eminem won't mention him, despite Eminem hates the guy and is afraid of him.

Eminem has always had a very dark sense of humour, most of his rhymes about other people were indirect blows, usually funny ones...he made a whole track of ICP giving oral to eachother...that doesn't mean he's apologizing for it, they wouldn't kill him over it, they probably laughed and got a little pissed off.

The Ja / 50 thing is obviously a big focus. Ja had the audacity to throw in verses about Em's kid, what kind of punk is Ja? I would knowck him out myself if he wasn't surrounded by protection all the time. He basically said "Your girl will be a whore and an addict", despite the fact that Em is a great father and she will grow up to be just fine. Possibly with minor troubles as all famous people's kids get, but she will not be like her mother unless Em loses his custody (which will never happen). Even still, Kim is recovering from her issues, Eminem saying the things he has about her doesn't help, but in a way she deserves it.

Anyway, I'm getting off topic. Let's talk about 50 for a minute. 50 had two major attempts on his life just because he was good at his game. He has good reason for his ways of calling out wannabe gangstas, they hired someone to kill him because they couldn't do it themselves. 50's beef is a very serious one. Em's beefs are because he isn't afraid to tease people who deserve to be teased, and now some of them are taking it overboard, by threatning and even killing his people. Now he's caught up in the 50 thing for producing "Get Rich Or Die Tryin'" and letting it hit the stores. But Ja deserves what was said about him, 50 had to defend himself, or he would become a punk just like those he calls out in his raps.

This song is about all of the feuds, not just the ones mentioned specifically. There are problems we don't even hear about, and for good reason. The people involved are just way too vicious. I'm surprised Em even wrote the Suge thing, obviously Suge has said something about Em, now that he is so close to Dre. Although it's comical in a way, Suge even hung Vanilla Ice out a window once and was about to drop him to his death, all in an attempt to extort money (note - Suge and extort used in the same verse, definately coincidental, though). That is the type of person Suge is. Em and 50 have no problem going after the wannabes. But Em won't dare mention Suge. Suge's methods of running a business is pretty much ike the mob used to run the garbage business in New York.

Em didn't use ICP for fanbase, yes the flyers exist, I know because I actually have one on my wall. The thing is, though, Em didn't make the flyers, and ICP would say they would be there a couple times, and sometimes whoever made the flyers would be told to put that information on them but the promoters.

One thing I am wondering, is that the Vibe Award incident hapened mid November, and the Encore album was released mid-December. The song was probably already written and all before the incident, which makes the song somewhat of a prediction of something that could have been worse than it was. Put a few things together, you may have a conspiracy theory. Em is about to release something mentioning Suge, Suge already hates Dre, Suge hires someone to go after Dre for allowing Em to put the song out. Last minute decision of censoring Suge's name would make sense, wouldn't it?

The rap game is full of this stuff and has been since the early 90s. The song is a very forward attempt to get these wannabes, and true gangstas to stop what they are doing, because enough has happened already. You get all the talkers and all the doers not knowing who's who anymore and people get attacked or killed over things like money or label issues and the like.

Good job, Em...never drop out, unless a life depends on it, just like you said!Edited by random_monkey on January 29 2006, at 09:25AM

comment_171:
Eminem is quite the humanitarian for his role on this song. 

Right. 

I was amazed at the number of comments on here that were in support of what a great message this song is sending and how amazing Eminem is. I'm not here to disrespect anyone's opinion. And if you find some greatness in this man's work, then good for you. Personally though, I have no sympathy for Eminem based on the issues presented in the song (or any other song, for that matter). This was touched on in an earlier post, but it's pretty ironic how one can trump themselves up to be such a "bigger man" when they've caused so much unprovoked drama to start with. And no, I don't really care if you can name instances where Eminem was 'victimized' into "drag them in battles that...he absolutely [has] to" participate in. And if this whole song is about stepping up and letting drama go, does Eminem "absolutely have to" battle anyone? Maybe I'm lacking the logic that undertakes a vengeance as such. 

Regardless, I just can't be swayed into agreeing with anything Eminem writes. Moby summed it up well in an interview responding to his diss from "Without Me": he basically said that he couldn't take Eminem's new approach seriously when just a few videos back, he was running around in a Bin Laden costume. 

I'm also really sick of the whole playing up the "Hailie" deal. Criticizing Ja Rule for mentioning his daughter's name on a track is understandable. However, with lyrics like "bitch I'ma kill you" and "you gonna hate me more when you find out you can't escape me, whore", I again, have trouble empathizing with his so-called morality and maturity, especially as a parent. 

"em is the best thing that happened to rap, anyone who cant see that is just plain stupid" 

This poster (and many others) may be right about plain, but not stupid. If you think songs like "Kill You" and "Shit On You" are epitomes of the greatness in hip hop culture, you sure are missing out. Have some pride in what you listen to and represent. It's crazy how an artist like this is idolized while lyrical geniuses (with TRUE messages) like Talib Kweli and Common are left ignored. 

Open your eyes, people.

comment_184:
bigmanoncampus asked-

"Who is Suge"

Suge (pronounced 'Shoog') is Marion Knight, the founder of Death Row Records, who Dr. Dre used to work for.

Dre wanted out of his Death Row contact because he saw that the company, which was engaging in numerous illegal activities besides producing rap music and had known gang members working for it, was about to take a fall.

Suge let Dre out of his contract but brought a bunch of gang bangers to his house with bats and said that all Dre's master recordings belong to Death Row, not him. That included I beleive unreleased stuff that Death Row had not laid claim to yet.

Dre left Death Row and started Aftermath Records. Soon after, Tupac Shakur was murdered in Las Vegas with Suge in the car. Many have long thought Suge had something to do with the Tupac hit, as he was about to leave Death Row as well and audit them for some $10 million they owed him.

Em says this line because Suge has had his other rappers and himself diss Dre for being fake and for deserting Death Row. Dre has tried to let it go, but Suge keeps trying to push his buttons.

Em never knew Suge and wasn't there for their falling out, thus he would be "talkin' about something, I knew nothing about". However, Suge was "all over TV, down talkin a man (Dre), who literally saved my life" and Em felt he now had to answer somewhat to Suge because of how loyal he is to Dre.

comment_190:
Alright, I know it's been said at least once, but I'd like to return to the idea that thing site is called SONGMEANINGS, not "Let's bicker about how important the artist is" Obviously if you're on this page you have an opinion about the song. Everyone is entitled to their opinions, but how about doing that in the forums? This is for talking about what the song means. I just read through 8 pages of mostly bickering. And I did read through each and every comment, and if you were to do the same you'd see how childish it all is. Bickering over spelling and grammar and how much money you all make? Frankly, I don't care what you do for a living or how much money you make or what have you. Also, as long as what you are writing is legible and understand able, I'm sorry, it doesn't make you any less intelligent if you mispell a word or create a grammatically incorrect sentence. I'm sure we all understand what is written, and if we don't, oh well, move on to something else. Or ask for clarification. 

Also, people that don't like Eminem? you're entitled to your opinion. But by coming to this page and saying you don't like eminem, and that you can say that because you're entitled to your opinion, you're very plainly looking to start trouble. Honestly, can you tell me that if someone went to your favorite song or band's site and said they sucked, wouldn't you defend them? I'm sure you would, and if you wouldn't, then I suppose they aren't really your favorite, are they?

Finally, why do people continuously ask the same questions over and over? If, instead of going to the end of the comments and asking a question that's clearly been answered forty times and getting angry when it's not answered again, why not read the comments before you send one, and perhaps your answer will be there? I realize that's a lot to ask on a page like this where there's pointless crap in between every meaningful addition, but skim. do your best. Don't post the same question forty times. 

Sorry, had to get that off my chest. 

I do like Eminem, and I feel this is a powerful song in that it really is a message to his fans NOT to be stupid. A lot of problems with "beefs" between artists stem from media hype and fans getting angry at one another. Eminem doesn't want that. Yes, he stirs up his fair share of trouble, and I won't say I respect every one of his songs, but a song like this one DOES send a powerful message, and I think that's hard to disagree with.

Also, an artists lyrics are his/her personal business. They create them from themselves, their experiences, and their views.  So, if you don't agree with what they say, that's fine, because you're not them. get over it.

And, with that I'm going to apologize for my billion word entry to an already overflowing comment page. 

-Z

Well, everyone sems to ask over and over "What does toy soldiers mean. Well, firstly, I'm here to dispell the thought that Eminem wrote the chorus to his song. He didnt. It (like a few other songs he has) was taken from another song. The chorus came from "Toy Soldiers" by Martika, an 80s singer. 

The lyrics for that song are as follows:

It wasn't my intention to mislead you
It never should have been this way
What can I say

heart to heart, 
left right left
We all fall down like toy soldiers
Bit by bit torn apart 
We never win
But the battle wages 
on for toy soldiers
It's getting hard to wake up in the morning

How could I be

all the pain

heart to heart, 
left right left ...

In my personal opinion, he's a great rapper. He sings from the heart in many of his songs. He raps to a different beat (ah-hah-hah, pun fully intended) than most rappers. However, the last part is my opinion, so of course, you can take it for face value.

comment_201:
"It was nice of Songmeanings to remove my posts. This sounds like something that would happen in Soviet Russia. Instead of promoting possibly conflicting ideas, they act like Pravda and removing anything that could be against the status quo. Hooray for America right? I mean, without the first amendment, many artists wouldnât even be able to make some songs. Thus, Songmeanings may not have been so big. So the same thing that protects the content Songmeanings is based on is denied to me? Way to go. You guys are real Americans [the owners, like myself are American]. 
For everyone who was looking for my old posts, I may have a way to resurrect them. 


-It really is inconvenient being so goddamn right. When Galileo said that the earth revolves around the sun and not visa versa, he was labeled a heretic and places under house arrest. I just get my posts removed. Fancy that. 

-R"


Yes, you have a First Amendment Right to say basicaly whatever the hell you want, no matter how pointless, irrelevant, and generally stupid it is. This does not, however, mean that Songmeanings is obligated to waste their bandwidth by keeping it up. To compare Songmeanings' decision to remove your posts to KGB-esque actions is almost as hilariously wrong as your attempt to portray yourself as a Galileo-esque martyr. 

Believe it or not, I actually agree with some of your points about the general childishness of the whole rap culture. By and large, as a result, I avoid the whole genre. However, I'm not so narrowminded as to immediately write off every song that is produced by a rapper, as from time to time a song like this one, or Tupac's "Unconditional Love", comes along. "Like Toy Soldiers" is a song that I heard once, and felt compelled to come here to get the backstory on it. It tells a story, and a pretty fascinating one at that.

As for the people who say that they have a hard time buying Eminem's whole act when he himself instigated so many of his feuds, I can definitely see where you're coming from, but my personal take is that the man is simply growing up. He's at the right age to be doing it, and I bet a lot of his priorities are starting to shift. There's nothing wrong with that, and who he was 5 or 10 years ago shouldn't disallow him from it.

Chocolate:  I've had this discussion about whether rock requires more skill, or is better than rap.  I think their very two different animals.  I love rock.  My favorite bands include Hendrix, Zepplin, Beatles, Nirvana, Coldplay, and Radiohead.  I also love Bob Marley, Lester Young, Luis Armstrong, Miles Davis, oh, and yeah Eminem.  Every type of music has it's strong points.  Rap/hip-hop is based more on improvising with a good beat in the background.  Remember, though, that just because anyone can make a beat doesn't mean it's a good beat.  Eminem is a great producer, and an increadible story teller.  There may be more poetic artists out there, but Eminem is great at telling an intriguing story, as is proven by all these people posting on this forum.  Also, have you heard the covers of Jin and Juice(originally made by Snoop), and Boyz in the Hood?  They're both covers of rap songs by rock artists.  I don't like most rap, but then again, I don't like most rock either....there're just many more artists to choose from since rock's been around for so long.  

All in all, everybody does have their own taste, and there's nothing wrong with that.  If you have a suggestion of a good group that you think people will like, please let us know.  Just allow us to decide we don't like it afterwards.  Art is about expression, and that's what em does so well.  If you don't like his form of expression that's cool.  

Oh, and hey, does anyone else find it amazing that these types of discussions are arising from a rapper?  It's undeniable that Eminem has brought rap into the mainstream and caused a whole lot of discussion of it's place in our culture.  That can only be a good thing!

Peace Y'all
